answer_html: From this table we observe that \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is increasing on \({\color{blue} x \in (0,1)}\) anddecreasing on \({\color{OliveGreen} x \in (-\infty,0) \cup (1,\infty)}\).
answer_latex:
From this table we observe that $\displaystyle f(x)$ is
\textbf{increasing} on ${\color{blue} x \in (0,1)}$ and\textbf{decreasing} on
${\color{OliveGreen} x \in (-\infty,0) \cup (1,\infty)}$.
hints_html:
What is the sign of \(\displaystyle f'(x)\) when \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is increasing? When \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is decreasing?

We know from part (a) that \(f'(x) = \frac{18(1-x)}{x^{\frac{5}{7}}}\) and that \(\displaystyle f'(x) = 0\) when \(\displaystyle x = 1\). How can we use this to find where \(\displaystyle f'(x) < 0\) and where \(\displaystyle f'(x) > 0\)?

Note also that \(\displaystyle f'(x)\) has a vertical asymptote at \(\displaystyle x=0\). What can we say about the signs of \(\displaystyle f'(x)\) when \(\displaystyle x<0\) and when \(\displaystyle 0 < x < 1\)?
hints_latex:
What is the sign of $\displaystyle f'(x)$ when $\displaystyle f(x)$ is
increasing? When $\displaystyle f(x)$ is decreasing?

{(a)}
that $f'(x) = \frac{18(1-x)}{x^{\frac{5}{7}}}$ and that

$\displaystyle f'(x) > 0$?

$\displaystyle f'(x)$ when $\displaystyle x<0$ and when
$\displaystyle 0 < x < 1$?
hints_raw:
What is the sign of <math>\displaystyle f'(x)</math> when <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math> is increasing? When <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math> is decreasing?
We know from part [http://wiki.ubc.ca/Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2013/Question_08_(a) (a)] that <math>f'(x) = \frac{18(1-x)}{x^{\frac{5}{7}}}</math> and that <math>\displaystyle f'(x) = 0</math> when <math>\displaystyle x = 1</math>. How can we use this to find where <math>\displaystyle f'(x) < 0</math> and where <math>\displaystyle f'(x) > 0</math>?
Note also that <math>\displaystyle f'(x)</math> has a vertical asymptote at <math>\displaystyle x=0</math>. What can we say about the signs of <math>\displaystyle f'(x)</math> when <math>\displaystyle x<0</math> and when <math>\displaystyle 0 < x < 1</math>?
question: 8 (b)
sols_html:
Where \(\displaystyle f'(x) > 0\), \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is increasing; where \(\displaystyle f'(x) < 0\), \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is decreasing.

From part (a), we note that \(\displaystyle f'(x)\) may change sign at its critical points \(\displaystyle x = 0\) and \(\displaystyle x = 1\). We can construct a sign table to organize our calculations:

[c]@llll@ & \(\displaystyle (-\infty, 0)\) & \(\displaystyle (0, 1)\) & \(\displaystyle (1, \infty)\)
\(18x^{-\frac{5}{7}}\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
\(\displaystyle 1-x\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle -\)
\(f'(x) = (18x^{-\frac{5}{7}})(1-x)\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle -\)

From this table we observe that \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is increasing on \({\color{blue} x \in (0,1)}\) anddecreasing on \({\color{OliveGreen} x \in (-\infty,0) \cup (1,\infty)}\).
sols_latex:
Where $\displaystyle f'(x) > 0$, $\displaystyle f(x)$ is
\emph{increasing}; where $\displaystyle f'(x) < 0$, $\displaystyle f(x)$
is \emph{decreasing}.

From
{part
(a)}, we note that $\displaystyle f'(x)$ may change sign at its critical
points $\displaystyle x = 0$ and $\displaystyle x = 1$. We can construct
a sign table to organize our calculations:

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llll@{}}
& $\displaystyle (-\infty, 0)$ & $\displaystyle (0, 1)$ &
$\displaystyle (1, \infty)$\\
$18x^{-\frac{5}{7}}$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$\\
$\displaystyle 1-x$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle -$\\
$f'(x) = (18x^{-\frac{5}{7}})(1-x)$ & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle -$\\
\end{longtable}

From this table we observe that $\displaystyle f(x)$ is
\textbf{increasing} on ${\color{blue} x \in (0,1)}$ and\textbf{decreasing} on
${\color{OliveGreen} x \in (-\infty,0) \cup (1,\infty)}$.
sols_raw:
Where <math>\displaystyle f'(x) > 0</math>, <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math> is ''increasing''; where <math>\displaystyle f'(x) < 0</math>, <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math> is ''decreasing''. 

From [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2013/Question_08_(a)|part (a)]], we note that <math>\displaystyle f'(x)</math> may change sign at its critical points <math>\displaystyle x = 0</math> and <math>\displaystyle x = 1</math>. We can construct a sign table to organize our calculations:

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| || <math>\displaystyle (-\infty, 0)</math> || <math>\displaystyle (0, 1)</math> || <math>\displaystyle (1, \infty)</math>
|-
| <math>18x^{-\frac{5}{7}}</math> || <math>\displaystyle-</math> || <math>\displaystyle+</math> || <math>\displaystyle+</math>
|-
| <math>\displaystyle 1-x</math> || <math>\displaystyle+</math> || <math>\displaystyle+</math> || <math>\displaystyle-</math>
|-
| <math>f'(x) = (18x^{-\frac{5}{7}})(1-x)</math> || <math>\displaystyle-</math> || <math>\displaystyle+</math> || <math>\displaystyle-</math>
|}

From this table we observe that <math>\displaystyle f(x) </math> is '''increasing''' on <math>{\color{blue} x \in (0,1)}</math> and '''decreasing''' on <math>{\color{OliveGreen} x \in (-\infty,0) \cup (1, \infty)}</math>.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answer and show your work. Full simplification of numerical answers is required unless explicitly stated otherwise.

Let \(\displaystyle y = f(x) = 63x^{2/7}-14x^{9/7}\). Determine the intervals where \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is increasing, and the intervals where \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is decreasing. (The results from part (a) may be useful.)
